author: d00dz
title: 3182 Review
review:
82 Airport Set:

Initial findings:

58cm (l) x 48cm (h) x 9cm (w)
1983 grams - Total
431 grams - Box Only

Pieces ?? (Need to count as it again doesnt say on the box! - Do that later)

When opening the box DO NOT open both sides! Just open one side only as all items will fall out both ways if you open them both sides!

so far the plane is larger than the 3181 plane.
Measuring in at 52cm long and 45cm long wing span.

Very easy to build. This time it has more interior than the 3181 plane, even has a split first class and economy section.
The two engines used real lego propeller shapes which was good. Cockpit looks roomy, despite having the main center console being a sticker. (Kinda sucked as the side panels were imprinted).
The front sliding door was definitely interesting, it replicated a real planes method of closing (if you have ever seen a plane shut, it is the same).

What I found annoying was the why did lego only give two engines? There is room for 2 pairs or even 3 pairs of engines. Even has the grooves there.
The wing lacked detail in my opinion, could have done more with it.
No landing gear that is retractable but I guess this is not a technic set so it shouldnt be moveable.

The front of the plane looks really good like an actual 747 plane.
The tail to my surprise did NOT have a sticker as it was imprinted on! :o I was going to turn it into a QANTAS plane but no go now. :(

The rear was just one whole piece which I found annoying would have been good to build the rear yourself or turn it into a cargo plane.

Pros:
Large!
Interior is pretty good
Door mechanism is good
Front of plane looks awesome

Cons:
Only two engines with option for more but werent supplied.
Wing span area lacked detail, as it was just one big plastic piece
Could have done more with the rear.

But overall I like it as it is a LEGO PLANE!

I had more fun building the small car and the minifigs than the plane itslef!

finished building the airport and the radio tower!

It was interesting. The airport had a lot of features. - Revolving door that actually turned, lights around the airport, security checkpoints, baggage xrays, a ticket counter with a computer, vending machine I think, radio antennas.


In summary overall as a whole the 3182 set is really awesome. It has so many componets and sections very fun to build. Initially after building the plane I was gonna give it 4/5 but now after building everything else Id give it 4.5/5. A must if you want to own an airport.

For the full review and many many pictures visit:

http://www.eurobricks.com/forum/index.php?showtopic=38089

author: LF1833
title: a new era of lego avation
review:
when lego relased the new passenger plane Ihad to buy it. when I got home I built it straight away. building was fun but it takes a long time.the plane is big and mesures out to be 48 cm long. the plane has 10 seats and 1 door.It comes with 5 minifigs 3 bag's and  1 passenger. the plane comes with 2 engins that are under the wing.the cocpit has  2 screens and some controls down the middle of the cokpit.

the termial has spinning glass doors, a vending machine, a cafe and a x-ray. how ever it does not have a air bridge.

Ibought this set on special but the prices range from $128.99 to $159.99 aud depending on which store you buy it from.

I really love this set  so I will give it a 5/5.

author: ogel646
title: must have for any LEGO city builder!
review:
This is an awesome set. It features 5 figures, one totally new female. I can guarantee that this set is way better than the previous one released in 2006. It has individual control tower, detailed terminal, transport cart, and a giant airplane.

The airplane has two seats in the cockpit, and another 10 seats for passengers. In addition, it has some nice details in the plane including a food processing corner.

The control tower is also better to be isolated from the terminal. It looks more realistic.

The terminal is a masterpiece. Although it's still small and definitely has more room for improvement, but for a $100 set, it's worth the money. It has both arrival and departure stations, as well as front desk and cafe lounge.

The luggage cart along with the stair is a nice addition, too.

Overall, for a $100 set, it's the best deal since 2009. I'm sure that this set is far better than garage, construction side, farm, and the new fire station.

author: jake9
title: Amazing Airport
review:
When I was a kid, I always wanted a LEGO airport. About 20 years later I finally got one. I got this at TRU's buy 1 get 1 half off sale. This set is very cool, folks. First, the terminal is fantastic. There are glass pieces at the front, and there is architectural detail with the curved pieces on the roof. The revolving door is amazing too, and is actually made up of four 6-high windows. The interior houses a coffee kiosk, a ticket counter, baggage x-ray areas, and a vending machine. There are some stickers in these areas, so be prepared to apply them. One of them mimics a board of departure and arrival times to various European cities. A nice detail. 

The control tower is very real-looking and fits the terminal style well. It has a clever radar setup on the roof that swivels easily. The interior allows room for only one controller, however. But the seat swivels and there are two computers and a lever which add nice detail.

The airliner is huge! It is wide enough to have the passenger seats side-by-side with an aisle down the middle. There is even a first class area and a baggage hold aft of the passengers. There is a microwave oven and some taps forward of the cabin. This set has many large pieces which are unique to the airport: The main wing, the nose piece that includes the glass already in place, and the tail which has a graphic that is NOT a sticker.

I added some road plates to make taxi and runway areas. This gave it a much more defined airport feel.

I know it's a bit pricey, but if you're a fan of LEGO City and/or aircraft themes then this is a must have set.

author: vlaky4
title: Way Better than the Older Airport Set
review: This set is just amazing compared to the 2006 airport set. There are two floors, which is a first, 2 security checkpoints, also new, plus a big airplane and a seperate control tower. The check-in desk is a bit plain. No scale for weighing luggage, just the desk and a computer. Security checks at both ends of the airport add one gate, because the older set had only one gate. Now the plane that comes with this and the passenger plane both have a place to be put at the same time. Another pro is the size of the plane. It is larger than the old set. There's also more minifigures to go with this, but why no control tower minifigure? All in all this set is perfect. I highly reccommend it.

author: mrmagoo7445
title: Airport of the Decade
review:
Now alot of people like short reviews so this is just dot points

Pros
- The revolving door which revolves
- The plane with now economy and first class
- Now there is a hostess instead of a second passenger
- Baggage Check on both sides of airport (Domestic and International)

Cons
- No air bridge only stairs
- Could have made four sets of engines instead of two
- No roads for the planes to land on

author: alva
title: Among the best set I owned
review:
Bought this airport a couple months ago, but I didnt have time to build it until last weekend.
My wife and I spend the weekend to build this set.
At first I thought that this set just another airport. But when we finished building it, I really amazed by the details.
The set have everything that should be available on any real airport.
They have everything, from check in gate, cafe, waiting area, control tower, cargo car.
And the building is really glossy with lots of windows.
Really love this set.

Good comments :
- The revolving door. Really cute!
- The details for the airport design
- Nice road lamps design
- The details for the plane design. Really love what the set own, with lots of chairs, microwave, water tap, and everything

Improvements needed to make the set even better:
- Reduce stickers. My experience with stickers is that they will loose their stick-ability after sometime, making the set look ragged and cheap. So I avoid using stickers.
- Add road plate for the landing strip
- Make it bigger
- Adding a couple of minifigs (for passengers of the plane, and also for security inside airport)
- Add stairs for connecting first and second floor

Overall, I really love the set. The building experience is fun, you can spend lots of hours for playing with the set, and when you display it, the set really look stunning.

author: The_Beast
title: I really like this set
review:
I really like this set because the interior of the terminal is so detailed.

Pros

  • Interior design of plane and terminal
  • Control Tower
  • Street Lights
  • Minifig amount
  • Lots of windows on the terminal

Cons

None

 

Overall I really like this set. My favorite features are the amount of windows and the designs on the insides of the plane and terminal. I do not like the Passenger Plane set as much as I like this set but the two work really well together.

author: SgtSmash
title: Big ol' jet airliner...
review:
The latest Lego Airport is a great set, if you have the room to include it in your town. The actual airport itself and the accompanying air traffic tower can easily fit into any scheme, but if you plan on having a runway, you might want to clear some space. The jet is MASSIVE.

 

I would liken this jet to an Airbus A380 in size comparison to the other Lego jets which have been offered previously. I'm not complaining at all, it's an awesome plane. I just think most people that have limited space in their town might find it a bit tough to incorporate it. The jet has room for 2 pilots in the cockpit, although the set only comes with one. You get 5 minifigs in all, the pilot, a stewardess, a runway worker/bag handler, one passenger (I felt for the price you should at least get 3-4) and one airport ticket agent.

 

The airport itself is pretty cool, but the interior could have been a bit more thought out. The downstairs has some kind of weird food/soda vending machine which takes up one whole section. The other side has the ticket booth/bag X-ray machine which is nice. The upstairs has a dining area with the other side being a coffee maker and more seating. Not a whole lot to the interior, but it is bigger than the last airport I had way back in 1985.

 

I've been a huge proponent of Lego including baseplates with their sets, and while this set is crying for them, of course none are included. If you wanted a realistic runway, you'd need at least 3-4 straight road plates, and spending the $14.99 USD for a two-pack of plates which contain only (1) straight plate is not very cost effective and still gives you nothing to set the airport upon. You're better off buying 4 large baseplates for the same money to set the whole thing upon. 

 

Overall, I like the set and it adds a lot to your town, especially if you already own the train station and the Public Transport. It takes a bit of improv, like the Lego Garage, to get it to mate to your existing town, but I think Lego enjoys you spending the extra dough to do so.

author: Timothywking
title: the 2nd greatest
review:
Now I got this set for Christmas and Ive wanted it all year this is an AWESOME airport.If you have the money I highly sugjest buying this.The inside includes:A coffie table,an unknown machine,a tiny tickets desk with a computer,and a coffie maker.

    pros:

  •     nice interior
  •     cool minifigs
  •     the airplane is very long
  •     open back in airport for good playability
  •     revolving door in airport!
  •     comes with rare pieces
  •     control tower is nice

  cons:

  •     needs to be bigger for $99.00

author: av8r1973
title: Big honkin' plane, realistic terminal and accessories - well thought-out
review:
We bought the "Passenger Plane" kit and quickly realized we didn't have any place to park it.  It looked way out of place in my suburbs of Creator homes.  So, we picked it up online in Taiwan (already out of the stores and shops....dang!)

My 5yo daughter built the airplane.  Holy cow, that thing is huge.  Much larger than the passenger plane.  Despite the single-piece formed wing, nose and tail subsections, it's a great build.  Sturdy, too.  The coach and first-class sections are nice, as well as the drink and food cart.  No potty, but...  A couple of drawbacks that kind of bug me.  The huge pre-formed pieces take away from the main attraction of LEGO.  Unfortunately, it reminded me of Duplo.  The jet only has 2 engines.  While this is the case for many airliners today, there is room for 4 and it would have looked more like an international liner if they had been included.  Since they are only 7 pieces each, it wouldn't have added any cost.  The landing gear isn't retractable.  Really?  I can understand on the Passenger Plane, but this has room for it.  Lastly, the tug that came with the Passenger Plane doesn't work with this one.  Simply fixed with only 2 Technic parts, it would have been nice to see them included.  How else do you back it up from the terminal?

Fortunately, the set was redeemed by the rest of the components.  The baggage cart is great.  Only one car for bags (3 included), but the air stair trailer is cool.

The terminal certainly makes up for the plane.  It's a great example of a regional airport.  X-ray machines, coffee shop. restaurant, and vending machines set the scene. The control tower is very cool (except for the obvious lack of a means for the operator getting to the top).  Due to lack of real estate in my apartment here in Taiwan, I put the tower on top of the terminal.  Once back home in the States, it will be in a dedicated location and separate from the terminal.  The revolving door on the terminal was much more sturdy than it looked.

There is a little fuel island, too.  It comes with a streetlight to match the rest of the City lights and a little fuel pump and oil drum (not sure I would trust fuel from a drum going into an airliner).

All in all, the set is necessary to complete the city. My seaplane and Passenger Plane and new airliner have a place to come and go from.  It's no doubt the best looking airport in LEGO history and has the most realism and playability.  Besides the preformed pieces in the airliner, the obvious lack of any sort of runway detracts from the scene.  A pair of plates would have been received with a warm welcome.  It's really necessary to achieve the look needed.  I would have paid a few more bucks for it.

Get this airport.  Either replace your old airport or relocate it to an unused part of town.  This one is great.  It won't be in stores forever, and it may be a few years before another one is released.

author: PistonCup74
title: There's So Much To Do at the Lego City Airport!
review:
I got this set for Christmas, and I really enjoy it. It had great parts, and lots of playabilty. I loved the control tower, building, luggage cart and all the lamps it came with. Goes great with 3179 (Lamp Repair), which I also got. Inside the airplane, I liked the seats, tables, sink, and 10 seats. I did use the man with the blue pilot shirt, smile face, and brown hair as a copilot. However, some major drawbacks are that there are lots of stickers, no jetway, and only 1 passenger. I also modified it and put the oven in the building and the soda machine in the plain. You almost never see ovens in planes, and most planes have a soda machine. The building was fun, although there were some huge pieces. The door also falls off alot, although I don't mind. Overall, I rate this set a 5/5.

 

I do reccomend this set!

author: BrickTVReviews
title: LCIA terminal 6 is here! New and improved!
review:
Welcome to BrickTVReviews with set 3182 Airport with 5 minifigs and costs 99$ Lets go on to the review. 

Box/Instructions

                         The box depicts the terminal, a tourist minifigure going to the plane, a stewardess welcoming the pilot, the mechanic marshaling the plane and the airport worker driving the baggage car with the ATC tower and fuel island in the background. The back of the box has 9 more snapshots of the set and the HEY! There are 6 instruction booklets, 1 for the bagage car and fuel island, 1 for the plane, 1 for the termminal and 1 for the control tower.

Parts

                          You get a frying pan in this set which is rare, the transparent cone pieces and red grill bricks, in other words, it is great!

Minifigures

                          5 minifigures are included with this set, 1 pilot, stewardess, mechanic, passenger/tourist and an airport worker. The tourist's torso has a new hawaiian theme torso which is cool.

The build

                          Not much to say....sorry.....

The completed model

                           The plane holds a red and white colourscheme. Its interior consists of 10 passenger seats and 2 pilot seats making a total of 12 seats. There are 2 engines on the wing, did i mention a refreshment table and microwave inside the plane but the cockpit doesn't support thrusters that is VERY dissapointing, it is replaced by a STICKER! The terminal has 2 seats in the lobby outside, a light post, garbage can and a parking sign. The interior includes a check in counter, 2 security checkpoints, vending machine, baggage claim and a cafe with 2 seats. The fuel island has 1 oil drum, computer monitor with handles and another light post. The baggage car? Nothing new and the ATC is boring but the glass panels swivels! p.s:I found a way to fit thrusters in the cockpit but im not telling you how!

Summary

                            I give it a 10/10!

author: legoboy1999
title: City Review of 3182 Airport
review:
This is a review of 3182 Airport,comes with 5 minifigures,a fuel island,baggage cart,control tower,airport terminal,and the huge airliner.The minifigures include a pilot with the wierd glasses face,flight attendant,runway worker,control tower guy and tourist with Hawaiian shirt.The fuel island comes with a computer,street light and oil barrel(I don`t trust fuel from an oil barrel).The baggage cart comes with the ladder cart thing and 3 briefcases.

Now for the airliner.Its big.Its so big,I had to place it on the terminal.Its mostly made from big pieces like the nose,tail and wings so its huge.A minifigure is dwarfed by this thing,that how big it is.It comes with a microwave and a sink and 12 seats.There`s no difference from first class to ecomony class except some tables.Also there`s two chairs and 1 pilots.Where is he!Apart from those minor problems its fine.

The Airport terminal is cool with its modern design and revolving doors and stuff.It comes with a cafe,x ray machine,advanced computer designs(a sticker),and a soda machine.Its great,lots of lights,and seating and its just great.The control tower has advanced radar system and for some reason,has no way to get up to the top except teleportation.Use my imagination.

In short this is an awesome set,I got it for my birthday,and its just awesome.

author: TheBrickLeaguer
title: This is a really good set to get
review:
I really like this set and I really recommend it to people ages 5+ and for many pros and few con too. They will be explained in the list.

Pros

  • The instructions were easy to follow.
  • The airport car can be seperated into three different parts(Car, actual baggage cart and staircase).
  • Useful parts(1x2 45 degree inverted slope brick, 1x6x5 panel, etc)
  • Plane is bigger than the plane in 7894 and 3181.
  • Very cool stickers(huge fan of both stickers and printed pieces).
  • Vending machine can be removed and replaced.
  • Plane seats 12 people(2 pilots and 10 passengers).
  • we're getting $114-$153 worth of parts, which is really good since this costs $100.
  • Good play value.(Which explains why this set was chosen for the top 12 for the 2010 Dream toys in the U.K
  • Stickers don't have to be placed across many pieces(for example, sign is 3 seperate stickers).   

Cons

  • Not enough minifigures.
  • Way too pricey because we are looking at 14.2 cents per piece for the price per piece ratio which isn't that great even though the value of bricks is good as said in the pros list earlier.
  • No runway included.
  • no staircase to the terminals second floor or the control tower.
  • landing gear doesn't retract.
  • Plane is slanted downward(front is 2 plates shorter than the back)
  •   
  • …

I give this set a 5/5, despite the cons. They don't bother me that much. That sums my review. See you guys next time.

author: Harmonious_Building
title: Thank you for flying LEGO Airways. (P.S. Our plane is huge.)
review:
Since I was a kid, I’ve always had it in my mind to own a LEGO airport, but, as one might imagine, the airports were, invariably, prohibitively expensive for my 8-year-old self. I’ve done a fair amount of travelling since those heady days of being toilet trained, or whatever it is 8-year-olds do, and I decided that it was time to treat myself to an airport after all those years of wishing for one, and so it was that I bought the latest iteration (as of 2011) of the LEGO airport for myself.

As with just about every modern LEGO set of this size, 3182 is divided into four distinct components: the baggage carrier/mobile staircase/refuelling station, the control tower, the airport terminal, and, of course, the airplane. Since the bulk of this review will focus on the airplane, I save that for last and address the other three components first. Also, as mentioned, this is the first and only airport set that I own or am likely to own, so I am unfortunately unable to make comparisons to other similar sets from years gone by.

To begin, the baggage carrier is more functional than anything else, able to hold three suitcases and possibly the landing lights (which I’m sure have a proper name). The staircase does line up nicely with the cabin door - as indicated in the official picture - and it also can be attached to the  back of the vehicle, so it does its job well. The refuelling pump is more of an afterthought that anything else, although I did not say no to cannibalising the street lamp for the rest of my city display.

The control tower is actually a surprisingly attractive component to the airport, as the windows are arranged in a 45-degree-ish angle that’s rarely seen, especially in the city line. The receiver above the control station does rotate, although to me it seems more reminiscent of small country airports than major international ones. Regardless, the control tower works well and looks good, so you’re unlikely to be unhappy with that.

The terminal building is probably the most disappointing aspect of the set. Certainly, it has its high points: the revolving door, the x-ray machine, and the ticketing counter, for instance, but it mostly feels cobbled together and doesn’t look particularly good from either side. The set’s relative lack of Minifigures (just five of them) also shows here, as you’ll find the terminal to be a ghost building if you’re just using the ones included in the set, and its deserted hallways will seem particularly ludicrous next to the massive airplane that has come in to land. I have the terminal building arranged so that its back is facing me, and it now serves as a weird sort of mall in which one needs to have one’s bags x-rayed upon entry. Given the sheer number of police stations that the LEGO city seems to have, though, I’m sure that LEGO city residents are used to such Orwellian surveillance methods by now.

The best part of this set is undoubtedly the airplane, and it is massive. Measuring at 51 cm (20 inches) from tip to tail and with a wingspan of roughly 48 cm (19.1 inches), it is highly likely that this behemoth is not going to fit on your shelf the way you want it to, but more on that later. The plane itself features a spacious cockpit that has room enough for two pilots (although the set only comes with one) and a detailed cabin behind it. This egalitarian jet has no delineation among first, business, or economy classes, although who needs legroom anyway when you’re a Minifig? As with just about all of the modern city vehicles, the top of the plane opens easily so that children can add or remove passengers without hassle, or so that grown-ups can recreate the Miami Airport scene from Casino Royale.

In spite of its size, the airplane is relatively easy to put together, especially since it features a number of large specialty pieces in order to give it its attractive curves. The frustrating part of the construction was the myriad of stickers that need to be applied onto the plane; in fairness, most of them are fairly easy to apply, but I refrained from applying the ones on the wings themselves because I just knew that they weren’t going to be symmetrical unless I had a laser guidance system or something like that.

The presence of the large pieces, though, means that the plane sort of ends up having a very “un-LEGO-ish” look, but I do, in a slightly ironic way, perhaps, find that this is sort of a plus for the plane. Because of the plane’s size, I found that I was unable to properly integrate it into the rest of my city display, and so I was pleased to find out that the airplane actually looks very good as a standalone model. Your own predilection towards a solution like mine will probably vary based upon how much affinity you have towards the romance of air travel, in spite of all the suffering associated with it, and I personally am very pleased to have my own model airplane that can encompass all the travelling I’ve done in the years gone by.

But, awkward ruminations aside, this iteration of the LEGO airport is a nice set to have if you don’t already have one of the previous airports. The feature-heavy plane and terminal will probably make the set more appealing for children than for adults, although, as mentioned in excruciating detail, the plane does serve as a very attractive model on its own, in my opinion. Lack of Minifigs and a relatively boring terminal building (appearance-wise) may cause some to shy away. Ultimately, for AFOLs, I really do suspect that the mileage that one gets from this set will vary proportionately with how much sentimentality you attach to airports and airplanes, and for me, I attach a whole lot of it.

author: benhjt
title: Airport review
review:
A present from the wife, a great addition to any lego city builder, had fun building this set, thinking of getting more planes to my collection (since i got the airport already).

 

the control tower and the airport is quite nice. the only missing part is the runway track.

 

Overall a 4/5.

author: jonnytheagent
title: Maybe best airport?
review:
Here is my review of the airport:

Pros

  • Big airplane with 10 passenger seats 
  • Cool terminal with little coffee shop and coffee maker 
  • The revolving door is cool
  • Tower has much details

Cons

  • There is place for two pilots, but only one is included
  • There are not enough airport customers 
  • The stair at the little car (I don´t no what it´s called) is a little bit unstable, but not much
  • The passengers has to wait out of the terminal

All in all it is a cool playset  and for the price absolutely okay. I recommend buying for any person who likes airports. I think it is the best airport in terms of value for money.
